The website of Caleb Waldorf

mailGet in touch

I am an artist living in Berlin. Collaborating with writers, artists, curators, educators, designers, and software engineers, I have initiated and helped develop publishing frameworks, educational platforms, and online archives. The spaces and systems I work on are designed to foster collaboration and reconsider how we approach learning, publishing, and collective engagement.

Among the projects that have defined my approach is Triple Canopy, an online magazine I co-founded in 2007. Its fourth iteration, developed in collaboration with Astrom / Zimmer & Tereszkiewicz, introduced a reimagined archive and new publishing strategies, alongside an updated version of b-ber, an open-source system for producing publications.

Around the same time that Triple Canopy launched its first issue, I also began working on The Public School, an initiative that originated at Telic Arts Exchange in Los Angeles. The Public School operated without a traditional curriculum, lacked accreditation, did not offer degrees, and had no ties to the public school system. (After a few years in Los Angeles, the school spread to other cities.) I served on the committee of The Public School Los Angeles and The Public School Berlin and worked on the platform’s concept, methodology, and associated design and software development. By the end of the project, there had been more than two thousand proposals for things that people wanted to learn, teach, or see happen. These proposals were turned into hundreds of classes and thousands of meetings across three continents over a period of eight years.

Concurrently with time devoted to Triple Canopy and The Public School, I have collaborated on other projects, some self-initiated, some with existing institutions. A few highlights include: A Public Library, a space for conversations, presentations, the sharing of resources, and for collective reading, viewing, and learning, that was located within a city library, the Bona-Peiser-Bibliothek in Berlin; post at MoMA, originally conceived as an online hybrid of an archive, publication platform, and participatory network; and Version, an online journal for short-form writing and media work. I’ve also had the opportunity to participate in conversations, workshops, and lecture at many institutions.

Thank you for visiting, and please get in touch to find out more about my work or to say hello.

Footnotes

  1. If you’re interested in learning more about the ideas that inform my work, please read “Publishing as Relay,” a conversation I had with Anna-Sophie Springer about our respective publishing practices and more, which appears in Art Writing in Crisis, edited by Brad Haylock and Megan Patty, published by Sternberg Press, 2021.↩
  2. After co-founding Triple Canopy in 2007, I served as creative director until 2020 and then technology directory from 2020–22. Over that period, I conceptualized and helped realize different publishing frameworks, both in terms of individual formats as well as contributing to the broader publication strategy, and, at various points and in different capacities, was responsible for visual design, editorial design, software development, and creative and technical direction. Collected here you can find a small sampling of that work.↩
  3. Astrom / Zimmer & Tereszkiewicz are a Zürich-based design studio. Astrom / Zimmer & Tereszkiewicz’s focus is on developing applications and frameworks that enable novel methods for curation and narration of digital content.↩
  4. In addition to what can be viewed and interacted with at canopycanopycanopy.com, you can find out more by reading a press release published by Triple Canopy, “Announcing 4.0.” ↩
  5. I published an essay in Triple Canopy, “Working on our Thoughts,” which describes the concept behind b-ber. More technical details as well as instructions for using the system can be found in the open-source repository. In addition to b-ber, Triple Canopy maintains all of the content presentation frameworks—and the content produced with them—that were developed since 2007. With the latest version of Triple Canopy, visitors can easily filter projects by the different frameworks: the first was ALS, followed by Horizonize, Alongslide, and finally b-ber.↩
  6. Buenos Aires, Santa Cruz, San Juan, Philadelphia, the Bay Area and San Francisco, Brussels, Berlin, Durham, New York, London, Helsinki, and Vienna.↩
  7. Occasionally The Public School developed projects adjacent to the ongoing operation of the individual schools. Some of these include a reading group held in a Richard Serra sculpture as part of “A Machine Project Field Guide to the LA County Museum of Art,” (more information is available in the catalog published for the project, which can be download here); “There is nothing less passive than the act of fleeing…” a 13-day itinerant seminar organized in Berlin, whose program is archived online here (an essay of the same name, that is tangentially related to what we did in Berlin was published in the journal, …ment, and can be downloaded here); “A Public School” a project organized as part of Encuentro Internacional de Medellin (MDE11) (a newspaper we produced for the project can be downloaded here).↩
  8. The last version of thepublicschool.org, which was developed and maintained with Sean Dockray—the founding director of Telic Arts Exchange and initiator of The Public School and Aaaaarg—was taken offline a few years ago, but The Public School Los Angeles still has an on and off again program. There have been discussions between Sean and I to grabble with the archive of the project, which will hopefully happen in the future.↩
  9. I recently created a standalone website that gathers the list of meetings that took place at the schools from 2009–2016, scraped from a version of thepublicschool.org archived on the Wayback Machine, which can be found online here.↩
  10. A Public Library was organized along with Fiona Geuß and Fotini Lazaridou-Hatzigoga. An archive of the program can be viewed online here.↩
  11. post underwent significant changes in 2020, resulting in a streamlined website that focuses on essays. In contrast, the version that I conceptualized with the C-MAP team, included many content types, diverse organizational methods, an intricate system for connecting the MoMA collection to the website, and a social networking component. Collected here are a few examples of the original site.↩
  12. Version was published online between 2009 and 2012. Each Version editorial item adhered to the following formal constraints: a maximum of 500 words, 5 images, or 50 seconds. An archive of the site can be viewed online here and an EPUB that I made that collects what was published and has more information, can be downloaded here.↩
  13. Archive Kabinett, CCA Glasgow, Friends with Books, Gertrude Contemporary, Haus der Kulturen der Welt, KW Institute for Contemporary Art, Los Angeles County Museum of Art, Migros Museum für Gegenwartskunst, Miss Read, MoMA, MoMA PS1, Monash University Art Design and Architecture, Museo de Antioquia, ODD, Otis College of Art and Design, PROGRAM, Ptarmigan, Salt Beyoğlu, Tate Modern, Tel Aviv Museum of Art, transmediale, University of California San Diego.↩
